title: applications invited for gallaher trust s scholarship scheme
story: NORTHERN Regional College is currently inviting eligible higher education students to apply for The Gallaher Trust’s Scholarship for the   academic year.To be eligible, students must be aged , have a primary address in the greater Ballymena area and have been offered a place at Northern Regional College for September  to complete a two-year qualication in one of the following subjects: Foundation Degree Engineering Foundation Degree Business with Digital Technology Foundation Degree Computing or Higher National Diploma Creative Media.The Scholarship will cover course fees of up to pound, per annum.In addition to providing financial support to successful students, The Gallaher Trust has linked up with local employers to help improve employment prospects for Scholarship recipients.Eligible students will be required to complete a selection process prior to receiving any Scholarship Scheme funding. Initial selection will be based on a conditional offer from Northern Regional College, previous academic achievement and a personal statement written by the applicant. The final selection process will comprise of a presentation to a  of representatives from the College and The Gallaher Trust.The Scholarship started in , and the first two students to benefit from The Gallaher Trust’s Scholarship Scheme are first year Foundation Degree students, James McIlfatrick and David McGaughey who are studying Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering and Computing respectively.James, who is a former pupil of Dunclug College, Ballymena said the practical aspect of the course really appealed to him.“I wanted to continue my education after completing A Levels and felt the Foundation Degree at Northern Regional College would be a better pathway for me rather than going directly to university,” he said.“This two-year course will allow me to progress directly to the second year of a degree in a related subject at university. Although I am still in my first year of the course, I have already learnt new skills and I would recommend the Foundation Degree option and The Gallaher Trust’s Scholarship Scheme to other students.“I wasn’t really interested in staying on at school to do A Levels as I just wanted to concentrate on computing, so I decided to apply to Northern Regional College when I learnt about The Gallaher Trust’s Scholarship Scheme.“I’m really enjoying learning about the dferent aspects of the IT industry and I’m getting a feel for what area I might like to work in in the future. If anyone is thinking about applying for a Gallaher Trust Scholarship next year, I would simply say, ‘just do it.’ The Scheme helps with job opportunities and allows participants to get a good start on whatever career path they want to go down while also helping with fees.”Christine Brown, Vice Principal of Teaching and Learning at Northern Regional College commented: “We are delighted that Scholarship Scheme recipients, James and David, are enjoying their respective courses.“We partnered with The Gallaher Trust to help more young people in the Ballymena area to gain the skills and qualications they will need to build successful careers in their chosen area.“I have no doubt that the scholarships will be invaluable to the successful applicants in terms of helping them develop new skills, getting an opportunity to complete a third level qualication and securing a job in a sector they’re truly passionate about.”Roy Douglas, a Trustee of The Gallaher Trust’s Board added: “At The Gallaher Trust, our mission is to create jobs, develop skills and provide assistance to those from a disadvantaged background and through the Scholarship Scheme, we’re ticking all of those boxes.“We want to ensure that the Scholarship Scheme graduates have the opportunity to learn the skills and gain the qualications they need to carve out a successful career. “It’s our hope that the Scheme will serve to create a pool of well qualied and high“ly skilled young adults who will meet the needs of local employers.”The Scholarship Scheme will support six Ballymena students, two per year for three years over a two-year specic subject course. Applications are now invited for the   academic year.  For more information about the eligibility criteria and the courses available under the Scheme, visit: www.nrc.ac.uk

title: youth of the 80s disco is back
story: BALLYMENA Youth of the ’S annual disco is back on!There were fears the fund raiser for World Cancer Day would have to be axed due to Covid restrictions.But it, and other indoor events, have since been given the green light to go-ahead.And now it is full steam ahead for this year’s big night out which takes place in the Adair Arms Hotel, Ballymena on Saturday, Febraury  .“We will be supporting World Cancer Day, which is on Friday, February ,” outlined Alwynne McLaughlin, manager of the Cancer Research UKshop in Ballymoney Street in the town.Alywnne explained that those going to the s Disco in the Adair will be given discount on party clothes and accessories they buy out of The Party Zone in Greenvale Street in Ballymena.“Special thanks to Stephen Neilly, of The Party Zone, for doing this for us,” said Alwynne.In the past couple of years the ’s style Disco had to be axed due to Covid restrictions.Now they hope the public turn out in force for a great night’s entertainment, while at the same time supporting the very worthy cause.Street Collection on FridayCancer Research UKis holding a Street Collection on Friday, February .Tesco store in Ballymena are also collecting that day for the same cause.Meanwhile, the Cancer Research UK shop in Ballymena is on the lookout for good quality clothing, shoes !“We would be delighted to receive such items,” outlined Alywnne, adding they are also needing homeware, unwanted Christmas gts, CDs, DVDs and vinyls.”The shop manager thanks all who continue to support them - and invites more to get involved. “The people are very kind to us with their regular donations to the shop. Photo credit: Danny Lawson PA WireNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailHealth Minister Robin Swann has paid tribute to GP practices as their Covid- vaccine booster programme is brought to a close on Tuesday.Boosters will continue to be widely available from health trust vaccination centres, mobile pop-up clinics and community pharmacies across Northern Ireland.The minister encouraged members of the public to get vaccinated as soon as possible, as “the likelihood is that the trust vaccination centres will continue to be scaled back in terms of hours and opening days, as resources are increasingly directed towards localised pop-up clinics in dferent neighbourhoods”.Read MoreBooster vaccine signicantly reduces risk of death with Omicron, figures show“While we are continuing to make progress against the virus, we must not underestimate the risk it still poses for people and for our health service,” he continued.“The evidence is very clear - getting all three jabs is the best way to protect yourself and others.“While we want to keep giving citizens every opportunity to get their jabs, the current arrangements for adults cannot keep going indefinitely.“In terms of convenience and widespread availability going forward, there will not be a better time to get vaccinated than now.”“The delivery of our vaccination programme has involved an unprecedented effort across the health and social care system,” continued Mr Swann.“GP practices have played an absolutely vital and central role, administering close to . million vaccine jabs in total, including over , booster doses.“In paying tribute to their contribution, I want to emphasise that this mass booster programme has undoubtedly saved lives and protected many people from hospitalisation.“While direct GP involvement in administering jabs is now concluded, GPs will continue to encourage their patients to get vaccinated and get boosted whenever they come in routine contact with them.”On Monday, three new deaths linked to coronavirus and a further , new Covid- cases were reported by the Department of Health. By noon on Monday, a total of ,, vaccines have been administered in Northern Ireland.The figures show , booster vaccinations have also been administered to date.The booster vaccine offers “high levels of protection” against the Omicron iant and signicantly reduces the risk of death, new data shows.Protection against death with Omicron stands at around % for those aged  and over about six months after a second dose of a Covid- vaccine, figures from the UK Health Security Agencyshow.That increases to around % two weeks after receiving a third booster dose.The booster offers high levels of protection against hospitalisation, the figures also show, with the effectiveness of the Pfizer jab against admission standing at around %, dropping to about % after - story: Mandatory Credit -© Freddie Parkinson ©Castlederg Young Loyalists.© Press Eye - Belfast - Norther FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMandatory Credit -© Freddie Parkinson ©Castlederg Young Loyalists.Gillian Anderson, Local Democracy ReporterFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailGood Relations funding of £ has been withheld from a loyalist flute band in Co Tyrone after a decision by Derry and Strabane Council.UUP councillor Derek Hussey’s attempt to secure the monies from the Good Relations Fund for Castlederg Young Loyalists was rejected before full council.This was despite the Health and Community Committee recommending that only a proportion of the funding be withheld.The flute band had originally been awarded £, for an event which took place at Albert Street car park in Castlederg in July .However, concerns were raised at the time by Sinn Fein councillor Ruairi McHugh who described the event as “descending into a sectarian hatefest”.At January’s full council meeting Mr Hussey proposed that “council reject the motion that came from the Health and Communities Committee to withhold £ payable to Castlederg Young Loyalist Band”.Council chief executive John Kelpie informed members that it had come before full council saying: “Full council were minded that an amount would be withheld and that was put back to the committee to consider the quantum.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseUUP councillor Derek Hussey attempted to secure the funding for Castlederg Young Loyalists. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueUUP councillor Derek Hussey attempted to secure the funding for Castlederg Young Loyalists.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Councillor Paul Gallagher responded: “This proposal has come from the rejection of the proposal.“The proposal has already been passed by full council therefore it shouldn’t come before council again for another six months.”Clarying the situation, city solicitor Philip Kingston said: “The proposal was referred back to Health and Communities to determine the amount of funding that should be withheld from Castlederg Young Loyalists Flute Band.“That has now been determined by the Health and Communities Committee and the recommendation is to withhold funding of £.“That still requires ratication by this council because it is only a recommendation by the committee. On that basis the proposal is legitimate.”SDLP councillor Steven Edwards said he felt the sum of £ was a fair amount to withhold.Backing the proposal, DUP Alderman Keith Kerrigan commented: “I know there was a recommendation from the committee which we weren’t in favour of.“I would like to request a recorded vote on this proposal. I feel with council still going against the legal advice which was brought forward, I feel we have a strong chance here that we will have legal action against this decision.”The proposal fell with  votes against,  for and  abstentions.The recommendation to withhold £ from the Castlederg Young Loyalists was subsequently ratied.Related topicsDerry City and Strabane District CouncilMore On Derry title: end of an era as burger king set to move from belfast city centre location
story: The Burger King restaurant located on Belfast’s Donegall Place closed its doors after  years over the weekend.On a sign placed on the front door, it announced that it will not be closing down completely, and instead will reopen at a new location in Victoria Square in March .A notice read: We are moving. This restaurant is closing th January.We are relocating to our new home at Victoria Square .We would like to thank everyone for your custom and support over the past  years.Our new Victoria Square branch opens in March  where we look forward to welcoming you back.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseInside the Burger King Restaurant that has closed its doors in Donegal Place after  years, the restaurant is moving to the Victoria Square and will open in March . title: foyleside shopping centre in londonderry evacuated after bomb report
story: Foyleside Shopping Centre FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFoyleside Shopping CentreEimear McGovernTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFoyleside Shopping Centre in Londonderry is being evacuated after reports of a bomb being placed in the building.The security alert is ongoing on Tuesday afternoon, according to police. A spokesperson said “Motorists and pedestrians are advised to avoid the area and there are no further details at this stage.”I’ve received an update from the PSNI regarding an ongoing security alert at Foyleside Shopping Centre. The centre is currently being evacuated. No further information at this stage.— Gary Middleton MLAFebruary , In a separate incident, a school on Hawkin Street in the city was searched earier on Tuesday after an anonymous report that a device had been left there. Police later said they believed the incident to be a hoax after nothing untoward was found. Chief Inspector Clive Beatty said: Officers have conducted searches and checks both in story: PSNI officers in communities across Northern Ireland will begin wearing a dferent unorm from Monday, which will consist of a new style of trouser and a bottle green top to replace the white shirt and tie.It is the first time the police unorm has changed since the PSNI was officially formed in .Chief Constable Simon Byrne unveiled the new attire, which comes after trials of ious versions of the unorm and a public consultation.New operational unorm launch day @PoliceServiceNI @PoliceFedforNI Another step in our approach to a more modern Service . pic ywjbJcjxdN— Simon ByrneJanuary , “You will remember that  officers from a range of operational positions and locations took part in a three-month trial, and we sought your views when we conducted three social media surveys last year,” said Mr Byrne.Read MoreNew sports-style unorms could cost the PSNI over £m“The previous unorm has been in existence since the formation of the Police Service of Northern Ireland.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up It served our officers well, but it is right that we reviewed how effective it was  years on.”Mr Byrne added that reviewing the unorm was an “important part of our commitment” to ensuring PSNI officers and staff are provided with a safe, comfortable and high quality unorm in order to allow them to do their job.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseNew PSNI unorm launched on January . Credit: PSNI FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNew PSNI unorm launched on January . Credit: PSNI“The new unorm will be worn by officers up to the rank of Chief Superintendent,” he continued.“It is important that we equip our frontline officers with professional, modern work wear, which is fit for purpose. I am committed to ensuring that the unorm is practical and comfortable in support of our officers as they work to prevent, detect and target crime in our communities today.From today, officers will be wearing a new style of trouser and bottle green top to replace the white shirt and tie. It is important that our officers are equipped with a practical unorm as they prevent, detect and target crime in our communities pic ncJqpHICyA— Police Service NIJanuary , “A lot of work has gone into planning and seeking feedback around the new unorm. Our officers work at the heart of communities and, therefore it was also fitting that we listened to what communities thought during the pilot phase.Officers were consulted and feedback was also sought from key stakeholders, including the Police Federation, the Northern Ireland Policing Board, and Police and Community Safety Partnerships.“I believe the new unorm will help us to enhance the visible, accessible and responsive service we seek to provide to the community.”Related topicsPolice Service of Northern IrelandMore On Police Service of Northern IrelandMan in Bangor hospitalised Credit: Clf DonaldsonJim Clarken of OxfamCaoimhe de Barra of Trocaire FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueAndy Mayhew of PraxisAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailJanuary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailSome charity bosses in Northern Ireland are drawing down salaries topping £,-a-year, it can be revealed today.The head of mental health charity Praxis Care, Andy Mayhew, receives between £, and £, annually.This is around the same salary as Stormont’s First and Deputy First Ministers — who received £, each last year.In a special investigation, the Belfastasked  leading charities how much their Northern Ireland head, or most senior employee here, earned –  of them responded.The remaining charities did not respond to requests for the salary information.Of those who disclosed the salaries,  bosses received more than £, annually and at least four took home in excess of £,.According to the Charity Commission, which regulates charities here, there are more than , charities registered in Northern Ireland.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up While some of these are large, multi-national, all-Ireland or UK-wide organisations with hundreds of employees, many are very small and only have a handful of staff.Other big earners, aside from Praxis’ Andy Mayhew, were Oxfam’s all-Ireland chief executive Jim Clarken, who receives €,a year, and Trocaire’s all-Ireland chief executive Caoimhe de Barra, who normally takes home around €, , however due to Covid this was reduced to €,in the   financial year.Oxfam commented in their response: “As part of his role Jim Clarken is also a member of the Board of Oxfam International, which means sharing strategic responsibility for the entire Oxfam global network in more than  countries. The CEO’s salary is set by the remuneration and performance committee which is made up of three members of the board, known as the Council. All of our board members are volunteers.”Unicef Ireland’s director, Peter Power, has an annual salary of €, , while St Vincent de Paul’s national director , Andy Heffernan, brings home between €, and €, Agnes Lunny is the chief executive of learning disability charity Positive Futures, based in Northern Ireland, and Positive Futures Ireland, based in the Republic.Her combined salary for both roles is £, annually.In her response to this newspaper request, Ms Lunny said: “My average working week across both roles is + hours, more often than not  hours. That puts my hourly pay at between £ and £.“My salary was recently increased following a benchmarking exercise against similar roles in Health  Social Care.”All-Ireland wellbeing charity Inspire’s chief executive, Kerry Anthony, has an annual salary of between £, and £,. An Inspire spokesperson said: “You will see from our accounts that our income mostly comes from contracts for services with very little coming from donations from the public. Any donations we do get from the public to support our work go straight to the projects for which they are raised and don’t contribute to the pay of our CEO.”Ulster Unionist MLA Andy Allen, a member of Stormont’s Communities Committee, said he can understand why some may be concerned by charity bosses taking in large salaries, however the signicant amount of work they undertake must be taken into account.“The structure and complexity of modern charities require leadership and ability at the highest levels to ensure the organisation is managed effectively to deliver vital support services for their beneficiaries,” he said.“While I understand fully the public concern that salaries of some charity chief executives are over £,, it is important to recognise the experience and skills required to run an organisation that employs hundreds of people, manages millions of pounds of public money and donations — delivering vital services to our most needy and vulnerable.If an inidual could earn more in a similar position in the private sector, as is the case in many of these examples, then how can our charities attract the best and most qualied leaders to ensure services to those most in need are deliveredthey are not offering a comparable salary that recognises the skills and experience needed ”In December , it emerged that the then-Communities Minister Caral Ni Chuilin had commissioned an independent review of the Charity Commission, following a report by senior civil servant Jonathan Baume looking at how the Department for Communities handled complaints in relation to the Commission.Responding to an Assembly question about the Baume report’s recommendations by TUV leader Jim Allister at the time, Ms Ni Chuilin said: “The former Head of the Civil Servicecommissioned a review into how the Department for Communities had handled a number of complaints from a member of the public in relation to the Charity Commission.“HOCS asked my Department to respond to the suggestions set out in the review. These are currently being progressed, including consideration of the Department’s role as the custodian of charity regulation law and policy and sponsor for the Commission.“The Department’s Head of Governance has also written to the Chief Commissioner to seek assurances in relation to matters highlighted in the Review.“In order to restore public confidence in a system that has undoubtedly been damaged, I have also decided to commission an independent review of charity regulation including a review of the performance of the Charity Commission in its role as statutory regulator.”Related title: 87bn written off by government in relation to
story: A nurse putting on PPE  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA nurse putting on PPE By Jane Kirby and August Graham, PAFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailSome £. billion spent by the Government on personal protective equipmentduring the pandemic has been written off, according to annual accounts.New documents from the Department for Health and Social Careshow huge amounts wasted on useless equipment, while millions of pounds has been spent getting out of contracts or storing PPE at ports.According to the   accounts, some £ million worth of equipment was found to be totally unusable, and £ million was spent on items that were not used before their expiry date.Nearly £. billion was spent on “items not suitable for use in the NHS,” but which the department thinks can be sold or given to charities.The DHSC also said the value of its remaining stock had been slashed by £. billion as the price of PPE dropped."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk da .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_badaf-ffbf-e-ac-bbedf_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk da .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_badaf-ffbf-e-ac-bbedf_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " consignment of NHS medical supplies and PPE from China At the start of the pandemic, prices for protective equipment rose sharply as countries clamoured to get hold of items such as face masks.The accounts further reveal that the DHSC expects that equipment that was scheduled to be delivered after the end of the financial year will lose £. billion in value.The Government was also charged £. million for not moving containers full of PPE from a port to their storage facility on time.Also in the accounts is a loss relating to fruit and vegetables after the School Fruit and Vegetable Schemewas temporarily suspended when all schools were closed.The DHSC had already contracted to pay for produce to be delivered to schools, leading to a loss of £.m, which comprised distribution costs of £, and produce costs of £,.The DHSC said it had donated £, of the fruit and veg to food charities.Further losses recorded in the annual accounts include £. million amounting to the value of % of an undelivered order for ventilators “which did not fully meet ality requirements at the time”.The accounts said: “Consequently, the remainder of the order was cancelled. As the supplier had technically met the contract’s specication and had already incurred costs, % of the contract value was unable to be recovered.”During the year, the DHSC wrote off laboratory equipment valued at £, following the closure of two regional testing sites and “there being no alternative options for repurposing or storing these assets”.Additionally, a stockpile of intensive care unit items was created to prevent shortages.The reports said: “A small number of items, valued at £,, reached their expiry date and had to be written off.”When it comes to NHS Test and Trace, DHSC has “impaired… consumables totalling £ million in respect of items for which we have not currently identied a suitable use.”Two flights relating to the transportation of PPE from China had to be cancelled due to lack of stock availability at the time, and the £, deposit for the two flights was taken as a cancellation charge, “as per the terms of the contract”.The report also pointed to “changing requirements” which meant the DHSC incurred a cancellation fee of £, following the cancellation of two contracts for quarantine hotels.Interest payments were paid to a supplier totalling £. million resulting from the late payment of invoices as a result of an initial contractual dispute, which ended up in the DHSC being forced to pay.In the first six months of the Covid- pandemic in the UK use of PPE in England alone added an additional % carbon burden, compared with pre-Covid-. Between February and August , three billion items of PPE were used, resulting in  tonnes of waste per day. Much of this PPE use was unnecessaryWHO study of PPE wasteThe Government’s auditor, the comptroller and auditor general to the House of Commons, said in his section regarding the accounts that the DHSC was put under “extraordinary pressure” by the pandemic and had to operate outside normal processes and procedures.But he said it “was not able to manage adequately some of the elevated risks, resulting in signicant losses for the taxpayer. Nearly two years later, it has not fully restored effective control over some of the inventory purchased”.“The chief secretary to the Treasury wrote to the department on  December  confirming HM Treasury’s view that £. billion of the department’s spending did not have proper HM Treasury consent and was irregular. He stated that ‘in the vast majority of cases’ this was because either the department or NHS England had spent funds without approval or in express breach of the conditions that had been set.”It comes as a World Health Organisationstudy on PPE waste pointed to “unnecessary” use in the UK.It said: “In the first six months of the Covid- pandemic in the UK use of PPE in England alone added an additional % carbon burden, compared with pre-Covid-.“Between February and August , three billion items of PPE were used, resulting in  tonnes of waste per day. The greatest contribution came from gloves. Much of this PPE use was unnecessary.”Liberal Democrat health spokeswoman Daisy Cooper said the Government was “inept”, adding: “They cannot be trusted with our money and are totally out of touch.”Shadow chief secretary to the Treasury Pat McFadden said: “These levels of waste destroy any claim the Conservatives have to be careful stewards of the public finances.“Along with the Government’s laissez faire attitude to fraud, this will be particularly galling to hard-working households wondering how they will pay the higher taxes the Chancellor is imposing this April.” Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletter Receive todays headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.
