title: 48 schools facing uncertain future over low numbers
story: FORTY-EIGHT primary and post-primary schools in the Newry, Mourne and Down area face an uncertain future due to low pupil numbers.Statistics released by the Education Authority showed that a total of nearly % of schools in the area had enrolment numbers below the current sustainable threshold.The disparity in costs of educating children at schools with low numbers compared to well-attended schools was also highlighted.The EA launched its proposals to streamline education over the next five years which will go out for public consultation until April .Figures indicated that  Catholic Maintained primaries, eight Controlled primaries, two Irish Medium primaries and one Controlled Integratedprimary would face a review to find a sustainable model of provision through a phased programme.The consultation paper also showed that out of  primary schools in the area, ten had less than  pupils, which falls below the threshold of minimum pupil numbers.The average cost of educating a child in a primary with less than  pupils was calculated at pound,, compared to pound, per pupil for schools with over  pupils.The EA also plans to reduce the numbers of pupils taught in classes of more than two year groups.There were  post primary schools educating students from Year  to Year  which were deemed to be below a sustainable model mdashthatrsquos nearly half of all secondary or grammar schools in the district.These rural schools have less than  attending and are comprised of six Catholic Maintained, four Controlled and one Grant Maintained Integrated school.The cost of educating one student at a post-primary school with less than  pupils was pound,. For schools with over  students and less than , itrsquos pound,.The  schools will also be reviewed to help them achieve a sustainable enrolment level.The draft EA plan said ldquochange will be needed but it did not identy any inidual school which may be faced with closure or amalgamation.The EA area plan also looks at the structure of special schools across the region and said there is a need for an additional , spaces by .There is a total of  primaries and  secondary and grammar schools in the district area.The consultation and all related information are available to download at www.eani.org.uk publications consultations..prettyPhoto

title: Ardglass hoping for boost from £100m investment
story: ARDGLASS looks set to benefit from a share of a poundm investment proposed for coastal communities across the UK which could create a number of new jobs in the village.The news comes after the UK government and the three devolved administrations mdash including the Northern Ireland Executive mdash set out their agreed vision for a sustainable fishing industry.Stormont Fisheries minister Edwin Poots and his counterparts in England, Wales and Scotland are seeking views on their ldquojoint fisheries statement which describes legally-binding policies to manage the fishing sector.A consultation on the statement runs until April  and sets out plans for an ldquoecosystem-based approach to fishery management with a commitment to protecting and, where necessary, recovering fish stocks.Mr Poots said the new joint fisheries statement forms an important part of the overall fisheries framework.He explained that it sets out plans to pursue sustainable fisheries policies that will benefit both the fishing industry and the marine environment for many years to come and is encouragingeveryone who has an interest in achieving the UKrsquos vision of having clean, healthy, safe, productive and biologically erse oceans and seas to get involved in this consultation.UK Environment Secretary George Eustice, said the Fisheries Act provides the four home nations with powers to implement their own independent fisheries policy, improve marine environment and make decisions based on the health of fish stocks and not vested interests.ldquoWe are setting out our shared vision for a sustainable fishing industry that delivers for our fishermen, the environment and the whole Union. We have taken back control of our waters and a year on from the Trade and Co-operation Agreement a positive picture is emerging for our fishing industry, he continued.ldquoWe have seen an increase in quota that will amount to around poundm by  and are investing poundm into coastal communities so that they can benefit from better infrastructure, new jobs and investment in skills.Local councillor Dermot Curran is encouraging people to respond to the consultation exercise, to reduce the impact of fishing on the marine environment, as well as support the industry. And he hopes that all three Co Down fishing ports will benefit from the funding that is to be made available.ldquoI am keen to see more detail to see exactly how Ardglass in particular can benefit from financial support at a time when there is much focus on a range of work that is required at the village harbour, Cllr Curran continued.ldquoThe need to deepen the harbour to facilitate larger vessels is key moving forward, but the need to have a dedicated boat repair facility in the village has also been raised with me. Currently, vessels have to go where to be repaired.ldquoIf Ardglass had its own dedicated repair facility, it would not only be able to service local boats but those based in other ports. Investment to repair boats locally would also create jobs.Cllr Curran said everyone with an interest in the fishing industry should make the most of the opportunity to comment on the detail in the joint fisheries statement.ldquoConfirmation that poundm is being made available for fishing communities is excellent news and I hope that the ports of Ardglass, Kilkeel and Portavogie will be able to share this very welcome additional financial investment, he continued.ldquoThis is an important step forward and clearly Minister Poots is committed to the Co Down fishing industry and the processing industries and communities which rely heavily upon it. This new investment will help safeguard all their respective futures which is good news. The investment will boost the local and regional economy.Last year, it was revealed that investment in the region of poundm is needed to upgrade Ardglass harbour to help maximise the portrsquos future opportunities.The Fishing and Seafood Development Programme reportrsquos recommendations for Ardglass included enhancing capacity at the harbour to provide security for fishing and processing businesses,The report revealed that a survey of the harbour walls in Ardglass showed that some repairs may be required within the next one to two years but their condition will not prevent the deepening of the harbour mdash to nine metres below the waterline mdashthey are stabilised and protected from undermining prior to dredging operations.It says the current water depth and quaysideprevents larger fishing vessels from landing at Ardglass with tankers transporting fish landed in Belfast to the village for processing. Mackerel and Irish Sea herring continue to be landed in Ardglass.The report said there is inadequate space for growing the inshore fleet at the port as the quayside is dominated by the larger demersal fleet and occasional visiting pelagic vessels, with the adjoining marina for the exclusive use of leisure craft.It was also noted that a constraint to the landside development of the harbourrsquos estate is the mixed ownership of existing properties which prevents the Fishery Harbour Authority from having full control over activities at the port and limits the ability to plan strategically..prettyPhoto

title: Caoimhe raises £900 for turtle rehabilation scheme in Maldives
story: WHEN it comes to conservation, Downpatrick woman Caoimhe Morgan-Burns practices what she preaches.The  year-old has raised pound by collecting rubbish from the sides of the Ardglass Road and Ballysallagh Road.The money is to go towards the cost of a pound, trip to Naaru Island in the Males in June where Caoimhe will devote four weeks of her time to volunteer at a sea turtle rehabilitation centre.The trip will mean a lot to Caoimhe, a former pupil at Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle, as she will head to Bristol University in September to study Wildle Ecology and Conservation Science.Caoimhe plans to plant some trees on her familyrsquos land so and is thinking up of other fund-raising initiatives towards the cost of the trip.She spent over five hours removing rubbish from the edges of the road and was dismayed by how much she collected from her own home road.ldquoI collected  bin bags full of rubbish. I am planning on doing it again for a day as there was so much more that I could have gotI had the time, she said.ldquoI was driving up the road today and noticed that it seemed to be as bad again which is frustrating.Caoimh will be part of a lsquoGoEcorsquo expedition to look after injured sea turtles.She explained: ldquoThe purpose of the centre is to rescue injured Sea turtles from the wild and provide daily care including medical treatment and rehabilitation exercises until they are fit for release.ldquoIt also runs a head start program for turtle hatchlings that have previously been illegally kept as pets by people in the Males.ldquoVolunteering on a sea turtle conservation has always been a big dream of mine and now that Irsquom going to university to study Wildle Ecology and Conservation Science, itrsquos the best time to take this opportunity.To support Caoimh visit the Go Fund Me site at https:gofund.me fcbe..prettyPhoto

title: Children among winners in calendar competition
story: TASTY dishes were on the menu for pupils in Downpatrick last week with two schools taking delivery of substantial meat packages.Down High School and De La Salle High School were among winners of the annual MeatSchools competition hosted by the Livestock and Meat Commission.The competition is a highlight in the Commission calendar and each year pupils from across the province are invited to profile the signicance of Northern Ireland Farm Quality Assuredbeef and lamb to the local industry and as part of a healthy balanced diet.Creative juices flowed as pupils produced original recipes with NIFQA beef and lamb as part of their competition submission.The three winning recipes were brilliant beef burgers, lamb stew and spaghetti bolognese. The winning schools each received pound of NIFQA beef and lamb, kindly sponsored by ABP Food Group.Livestock and Meat Commission education and consumer promotions manager, Sarah Toland, explained that one of the key drivers for the competition was to encourage the use of NIFQA beef and lamb in schools and to complement the organisationrsquos existing schools programme.ldquoWith this in mind we specically targeted food and nutrition teachers and their students when drawing up the criteria for the project, she said.Sarah congratulated the winning schools, noting that as the competition received an encouraging number of entries, to select the top three was no easy task.De La Salle teacher Irene Stokes said the competition helped increase awareness of the importance of sourcing local NIFQA produce.She added: ldquoThis competition allowed our students an opportunity to highlight the vital nutrients that beef and lamb provide and how both can add iety, colour,flavour and texture to any dish. ldquoOur students are also becoming increasingly aware of sourcing meats that have the NIFQA symbol and the impact this has on the local economy.Down High teacher Sharon McKee said the competition was a ldquofabulous way of encouraging students to consider the valuable contribution of red meat in their diet.She added: ldquoOur Year  pupils are currently investigating the nutritional and dietary needs of adolescence so this competition fitted well into our curriculum and brought the theory to le..prettyPhoto

title: Downe partnership to help map future
story: THE first meeting of a new forum involving health chiefs, hospital campaigners, trade unions and politicians to oversee service provision at the Downe hospital is expected to take place in the spring.The South Eastern Trust mdash which is responsible for the hospital and the delivery of a raft of health and social services across the community mdash has described the creation of the new Downe Health and Care Partnership Forum as exciting.Last summer, South Down MP Chris Hazzard suggested to senior health chiefs that a new partnership involving a range of key players should be established to help map out the most appropriate model of health care for the area and it will soon become a reality.Health chiefs said the forum, which is the first of its kind in Northern Ireland, said the two key objectives are to plan for the future with everyone who uses services in the area and work in partnership to improve the health and wellbeing of the community.The health trust said this is in line with the organisationrsquos so-called ldquoquality  all strategy which puts excellent care at the centre of what it does.Officials say the new forum will consider local population health and social care needs, support people to lead healthier lives and take action to reduce health inequalities.Health trust chief executive, Roisin Coulter, said the organisation wants to work collaboratively with the local community regarding existing health and social care services to plan and design for the future.ldquoWorking in partnership with a wide range of key stakeholders will be vital to the forumrsquos success. The Trust is committed to ensuring that everyonersquos voice is heard and their contribution will be valued, she added.While the terms of reference and the membership of the new forum have yet to be finalised, the South Eastern Trust hopes that an initial l meeting in Spring .Mr Hazzard said he is pleased that health officials have agreed to the creation of the new forum which could be formally launched shortly.The MP said it was vital that the local community and health workers are afforded an opportunity to be involved in determining the most appropriate model of healthcare at the Downe and throughout South Down.ldquoThis will not only enable the local community to benefit from regular public engagement and consultation but, perhaps most importantly, would ensure a real and meaningful process of co-design with staff and their trade union representatives, he said.ldquoThe creation of this forum is a signicant acknowledgment from the South Eastern Trustrsquos senior management that communication and dialogue need to improve in the time ahead.Mr Hazzard said elected representatives, trade unions and community health activists can play a constructive role in partnership with officials in delivering for the Downe.The MP is also confident that working in partnership, with a shared ambition to protect rural access to vital health services and improve health outcomes for all in our community, the new partnership forums can make a real dference in the years ahead..prettyPhoto

title: East Down AC youths at District cross country
story: FOR many of the East Down juniors it was a busy week with the Schoolsrsquo District cross-country on Wednesday, as well as weekend races.District A, which incorporates most schools in Co Down, was contested in Delamont Country Park with a large entry across the age groups.Runners were there to represent their school team with qualication for the Ulster Schools event as the main aim.As well as qualying as part of a team, runners can also get selected as an inidualthey come in the top  of their race.Well done to all our juniors who took part and congratulations to those who are proceeding to the next round which takes place in Mallusk on February .Apologies to any who were missed from our summary due to being in school vests rather than their customary red and yellow East Down AC colours.Year  girls: Maeve McNeill, St Malachyrsquos, th.Year  boys: Alex Robinson, Down HS, th inidual qualier, Finn Gibney, Down HS, th.Year  girls: Cara Napier, Assumption, th inidual qualier, Erin Moore, Down HS, th.Year  boys: Conan Pleasants, St Patricks, Downpatrick, nd.Year  girs: Abigail Elliott, Down HS, rd, Rebekah Wilson, Down HS, th.Year  boys: Oliver Robinson, Down HS, th inidual qualier, Jacob Crawford, Down HS, th inidual qualier, James Wright, Down HS, rd.Year  boys: MacKenzie Murray, Down HS, th inidual qualier.International cross countryON Saturday the Northern Ireland International cross Ccuntry was held at Billy Neill Playing Fields in Comber.The main event was the elite racing mid afternoon when the top athletes in Northern Ireland and Ireland went head to head with runners from England, Scotland, Wales and those from further afield.There was a full team of Italian athletes and olympic and world record standard entrants, so the spectators were kept fully entertained.Before all this, however, there was a mixed K club race for both male and females of all age categories. EDAC had five runners who took part. Neil Curran had a decent run to lead his clubmates home in seventh place.With . as the total time run, he found it rather short and sweet, but challenging nonetheless due to the hilly route and the leg sapping mud.Mackenzie Murray really enjoyed his outing, coming th in ..His dad, Dee, was th in . and Adam Morgan paced it well to come th overall.Catherine OrsquoConnor was the only EDAC female but despite the back-up of a team, she went out hard and after a mid race tussle for the lead in the female category she settled into second place which she held until the line.Those who took part saw it as good practice for this weekend coming when the club will turn out in force for the NI and Ulster Masters and Intermediate Championships which take place at Queenrsquos Playing Fields in Belfast.When Ashling Murphy lost her le in tragic circumstances ,whilst out running mdash something that she loved and where she should not have been at risk mdash it struck a note with the running community both near and far.Runners were shocked that one of their own was so cruelly and tragically taken and in an attempt to find a positive in the depths of despair there have been some gatherings over the past week to allow them to express solidarity.One such event was organised by Ballygalget AC on Sunday and a large number gathered in the Exploris car park in Portaferry to run K together in her memory.Runners were invited to donate to Womenrsquos Aid instead of an event fee and as a result a signicant amount was raised for this worthy cause.Suzy Smith, accompanied by her brothers Donal and Patrick, made the trip and Mags Flynn also took part.RIP Aisling..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  January 22%2C 1992
story: DOWNPATRICK ndash An announcement is expected shortly that the multi-million pound ring-road for Downpatrick has been abandoned.The Government is believed to have given the thumbs down to the scheme, along with another to construct a link road between Church Street and Scotch Street.South Down MP Mr Eddie McGrady, yesterday labelled the decisions as a ldquototal indictment of Government planning, and he has asked for an urgent meeting with the Environment Minister, Mr Richard Needham, to seek a reconsideration.The ring road, which would join the Ballydugan Road and Belfast Road, has long been viewed as the keystone to the Downpatrick regeneration project which was launched by Mr Needham over  months ago.At that time he came out strongly in favour of the ring road but the massive cost of such a project is believed to have swayed the Government towards the abandonment decision.What has further angered Mr McGrady is that the ring road replaced the Church Street Scotch Street link for which money had been available last year.ldquoNow that money has gone presumably spent where, so that no funds are available this year or next, said Mr McGrady. ldquoAt the time, when it was alleged that new studies were required. I accused the departmental officials of paralysis by analysis and unfortunately that has proved to be true.ldquoSince then, of course, the traffic congestion, which is now traffic chaos, has been greatly increased by the Irish Street closure, and it should be noted that not a single traffic management action has been initiated in the interval, he continued.NEWCASTLE ndash A cross-community unity campaign has been launched to save Newcastlersquos only public residential home from closure.Mourne House has been targeted for closed by the Eastern Health and Social Services Board but this week local politicians have joined with the Friends of Mourne House in mobilising public support against the plan.Representatives from the Friends group have already met with Board officials in a bid to persuade them to adopt a proposal from the charity, Age Concern, which is offering to take over the management of the  year-old home.DUNDRUM ndash Over pound, damage has been caused in another arson attack in Dundrum.Two caravans were completely destroyed and another badly damaged in the attack at the Bayview Caravan Site off the Dromara Road early on Saturday morning.It is believed the blazes were started in the early hours and two of the caravans were well alight by the time fire crews arrived on the scene.The incident is the latest in a long line of malicious arson attacks in the village which police believe are the work of a pyromaniac.Just before Christmas the villagersquos two primary schools were targeted with the Downshire Primary School sustaining over pound, damage. The arsonist has also attacked Dundrum cricket club, the orange hall and the parochial hall.BRYANSFORD ndash Plans have been announced to convert one of Bryansfordrsquos most historic landmarks into apartments, a craft shop and a restaurant.The former home of the Earl of Roden, close to the gates of Tollymore Park, will be converted into eight apartments, and an outbuilding will be extended to form a craft shop and restaurant facilityplanning permission is granted by the DoE.A further planning application proposes to build a number of luxury apartments on a site to the rear of the building, with an access from the nearby Burrenreagh Road.The building, which comprises extensive outbuildings and a courtyard, was used as a travellersrsquo inn during the last century when the Roden family lived in Tollymore House in the forest park.Since the destruction of Tollymore House the inn has been the home of the present Earl of Roden. In  it was the scene of an antiques robbery in which Lord Roden was tied up and threatened as raiders stole valuable paintings and antiques.Part of the outbuildings were regularly used by youth groups for residential weekends in the Mournes.BALLYNAHINCH ndash The job losses at the Ballynahinch GPT plant mean the lsquoBig Threersquo players in Down District industry no longer top the  jobs mark.GEC Plessey Telecommunications was the last of the lsquoBig Threersquo to employ more than  on one site.The lay-offs mean there are virtually no large-scale industrial employers left in Down.The GPT plant has been set on a steady course of expansion, even after the amalgamation of Plessey, as it then was, with GEC in . It took over the vacant Albion clothing factory on the Antrim Road and at one point last year was employing  people.The number has been whittled away and will be reduced to  employees.The other two major employers have also been hit over the last four years. The Shirley Tannery, owned by English-based Pittard Garnar at the time, employed  until its closure was announced in February . Although it re-opened later that year, the numbers employed has been dramatically scaled down.The decline in the numbers is even more pronounced when it is considered that in its heyday in the late rsquos, the tannery employed up to  people.STRANGFORD ndash There has been a renewed call for a bridge linking Strangford and Portaferry.The newly-formed Strangford Lough Bridge Project Group says a bridge across the Strangford Narrows is the only means of guaranteeing a continuous link across the lough.However, the group accepts that a scheme involving a barrage to harness tidal power would be environmentally unacceptable.Group chairman, Mr James McMullan, from Portaferry, said ldquoI believe there is overwhelming support for a bridge.ldquoPeople in Portaferry are concerned about the future of the DoE ferry service. A bridge has to be the ultimate answer. It would provide a link  hours a day and would not be subject to breakdowns, he continued.And Mr McMullan says he intends to seek the support of local councillors for his proposal.ldquoI accept a barrage would have environmental implications but a bridge on its own would benefit communities on both sides of the lough, he added.RACING ndash A campaign to introduce Sunday horse racing in Britain could result in Sabbath day racing coming under starters orders at Downpatrick.Mr Iain Duff, course registrar at Downpatrick, has given his support to the Jockey Club campaign and is demanding sweeping changes in legislation which prohibits betting on a Sunday.Mr Duff says Downpatrick and Down Royal ndash the Provincersquos other racetrack ndash should be allowed to hold Sunday meetings.Mr Duff says the law could be changed easily by making an Order in Council which would then enable tracks to hold meetings when people are most prepared to go racing on Sunday.He believes the move is needed to bring racing here into line with the Republic where Sunday racing was introduced some years ago.ldquoSunday racing in the Republic has proved to be a wholesale success. Surveys have shown more people go racing on a Sunday than on any other day, he remarked.ldquoYet the Northern Ireland Minister of Agriculture last November rejected the appeals of deputations representation Downpatrick and Down Royal seeking an equal opportunity.Mr Duff said thatSunday racing is permitted, the law relating to gambling would have to be changed.Mr Duff added: ldquoEverybody in racing respects the views of people who may be against Sunday racing, but I donrsquot think they should be allowed to dictate to the majority..prettyPhoto

title: Matthew survives on Dancing With The Stars
story: LOVE Islander Matthew MacNabb survived the first public vote in RTErsquos Dancing With The Stars mdash despite gaining the lowest number of points.The Downpatrick man was faced with the challenge of dancing the jive on Sundayrsquos show, known to be notoriously dficult for tall male dancers.Standing at ft in, the  year-old admitted it was tough going, but was personally delighted with his effort with professional dance partner Laura Nolan.Speaking from Dublin on Monday, Matthew told the Recorder: ldquoI was happy with my dance last night as I had a nightmare with it all week trying to get the timing and coordination down.ldquoThat was the best I danced it and I worked so hard all week but I guess giraffes arenrsquot meant to jive.In the end, it was novelist Cathy Kelly who was the first celebrity to leave the show.The local GAA player and digital marketing consultant said he had been overwhelmed by the support and votes he had received.He said: ldquoTo be bottom and to get through shows how amazing people are to vote for me and I really appreciate it. Thank you so much to everyone voting and supporting me. It means a lot to me.ldquoIrsquove never danced before so coming into the show, I am a complete novice and I really want to say at the end of the show that I can actually dance.He said the support from his home town and family was all the more special as he faced the public vote for the first time.ldquoThe reaction to the show was unreal. My mum called me this morning and said she nearly had a heart attack. She has the candles lit and was saying her prayers, said Matthew.ldquoMy two sisters, Nadine and Conagh, along with their partners Paddy and Sean came to see me so it was great having them there for support.Matthew has described his dance next show as a ldquoa complete switch up, adding: ldquoItrsquos going to be slow and graceful. With it being movie week, the audience are going to be brought to a dferent world.Before the live performance, Laura paid tribute to her partner as ldquoa hard worker who ldquoputs the hours in.ldquoIrsquove never met a more cool, calm, collected person in all my le, she said. ldquoI was expecting him to crumble ndash but he didnrsquot.Judge Loraine Barry was encouraging of Matthewrsquos effort to show  points and said: ldquoLetrsquos make this very clear, what is your biggest asset ndash itrsquos the feet ndash pumping, hopping, pounding, keeping that beat going. Thatrsquos all that was lacking ndash a lot more pump.Arthur Gourounlian commented: ldquoWith legs like yours you can kick to the moon and back, but I didnrsquot see that. Delayed, delayed, delayed, work on your musicality. I know you can do better, while Brian Redmond agreed, saying: ldquoIt just needs to be a little bit more on time. I liked the segments with the arms, showing potential there.Check out Matthewrsquos progress on Dancing With The Stars this Sunday at .pm on RTEacute One..prettyPhoto

title: New minister installed at Seaforde at Clough Presbyterian Churches
story: A NEW chapter in the history of Clough and Seaforde Presbyterian Churches opened last week with the installation and ordination of a new minister, the Rev David Bingham.Mr Bingham mdash who is the youngest minister in the Down Presbytery mdash succeeds former minister, the much loved and highly respected Rev Adrian Adger, who sadly passed away in January last year after a long battle with cancer.The address during the service was delivered by the Rev Owen Patterson, minister of Downpatrick Presbyterian Church, who helped out during the vacancy following Mr Adgerrsquos passing.During the service, which was livestreamed to the nearby church hall and to peoplersquos homes, Clough Presbyterian Clerk of Session, Mr William McCall and Seaforde Clerk of Session, MrDavid Croskery, both gave shortaddresses formally welcoming their new minister.Mr McCall also welcomed visiting clergy and members of both congregations to what he said was a special evening, thanking the PresbyteryCommission for its help during thevacancy.ldquoWe especially welcome Davidrsquos family, friends and associates to this very special occasion for us as a congregation of Clough and Seaforde. It is good to have Davidrsquos we, Sarah, and daughter, Susannah, with us who are very important members of the Manse family, he said.ldquoHaving met David on a number of occasions it is good now to be able to address him as the Rev David Bingham and assure him of our prayers for him and his family.Mr McCall said many people have been in touch expressing their good wishes, assuring their prayers for David and his ministry in Clough and Seaforde. He said many have stated the high regard they hold David in.ldquoWe give thanks to Almighty Godfor how he has guided in fulfilling the vacancy and bringing the Bingham family to the Manse. David is the nd minister of Clough and Seaforde Presbyterian Church since , he said.Mr McCall said it just over two weeks since the first anniversary of the passing of Mr Adger, explaining that the congregations still mourned his death and extending to Mr Adgerrsquos we, Karen, ldquoour continued sympathy and support for the loss of her loving husband Adrian.He added: ldquoWe pray that God will bless Davidrsquos ministry in Clough and Seaforde.Mr Croskery said it was his privilege on behalf of the people of Seaforde to welcome the new minister and pray for Godrsquos richest blessing upon him and his family.He also gave a brief history of Seaforde church and also remembered the work and ministry of Mr Adger.ldquoWe take great comfort knowing that Adrian is with the Lord and may we continue to pray for Karen in the years ahead, he said.Mr Croskery asked for Godrsquos blessing on the new minister as he begins his ministry in Clough and Seaforde.Following the service of installation and ordination, supper was served to invited guests in the adjoining church hall.Local councillor Alan Lewis, who is a member of the Clough and Seaforde congregation, attended the service.He welcomed Mr Bingham and also said he had many memories of Mr Adger.ldquoI am reminded of his commitment to our church, village and community. I personally reflect on his Christian guidance and support throughout his time at Clough.As we enter this new chapter with David and his wonderful family we take strength from those who have gone before.He added: ldquoOn behalf of the community I warmly welcome Rev Bingham, his we, Sarah, and their daughter, Susannah, to not only our church but our community.ldquoI trust and pray that they will make our village their home and enjoy many years of success and future happiness at Clough..prettyPhoto

title: New record for Ciara
story: PORTAFERRYrsquoS Ciara Mageean made a dream start to this yearrsquos indoor season by breaking her own Northern Ireland  metres record.The  year-old sprinted to victory at the World Indoor Silver Tour meeting in Manchester at the weekend in a lightning quick time of :..This was enough to shatter the previous record, which she set at Athlone in , by over one full second.Sitting in second place for most of the final lap, she had no intention of running out of gas and overtook Albaniarsquos Luiza Gega with an impressive burst to take gold.Her latest record-breaking run edges Maggean closer to the Irish record of :., set by Mary Cullen in ..prettyPhoto

title: Spa looking unstoppable
story: SPA GOLF CLUB............ ST MARYrsquoS KrsquoLEAGH.... THE big match of the week saw the top two teams face off against each other as the league leaders from Killyleagh made the trip to Spa to face the only team to have beaten them this year.They were just left to pick up the crumbs as the hosts continued their unbeaten run which led to this big win that no makes them favourites for the league with two games in hand and only eleven points behind with four rounds left to play.Davy Cavan, Paul and Don McNamara were up against Stevie Brown, Kieran McMullan and Ricky Cathcart and after four ends it was all square at -. But then Don upped the pressure and the hosts dominated thefinal ends to run out - winners.On the other mat the home triple of Hilary Cavan, Robin Horner and Graham Christie were playing some great bowls against Paddy Murray and after lting a count of six on the third end would only lose three ends in their - win. At the break the home side had a -shot overall lead.The Saints made a slight comeback in the third game as Philip Woodside, David Anderson and Neil Brown continued their good run of form against Frances and Derek McCann and skip Alan Laughlin, who after losing the first two ends won the next three to go - up before Alan hit back to make it it - after seven ends.This would be as good as it would get as the visitors won the last three ends to finish - winners to secure the only away points of the match.A mention must go to this triple for playing and controlling this game so well, especially as Philip had a throwback to past times with the quality of lead bowls.The last game of the night saw Rose Marie Wylie, Davy Vance and Peter Christie score seven shots from the first two ends against Terry Quinn, Nigel Brown and Tony Ward.They never relinguished this lead as the game finished - in their favour to secure another great win.Surely now no-one can stop Spa from continuing on and finish the season unbeaten and as champions.DROMARA..................... OWENBEG..................... DROMARA made their second trip to Owenbeg and got their best result of the season.They came away with a well deserved draw, but will be thinking they should have had the overall win.On mat one Jim McNeill, Brian and Ann Marie OrsquoHare were playing E Milligan, Marc Crothers and Sean Toman.They shared the end wins and at the end nothing could separate them as it finished -.On the other mat Mark Brady, Niall and Michael McGreevy were involved in an equally close game against Isobel Rooney, Damian Tumelty and David Gibson.After nine ends found themselves three up.Davidrsquos triple tried their best on the last end but could only manage to score two shots to finish - down.With only a couple of shots in it at half-time it was all still to play for. Dromararsquos Denis Kane, Richard Kelly and JamesMcKinney took control of their game against Haydn Tumelty, Dermot Rooney and Liam Higgins and even though they won only four ends and scored  shots to win -, this left Dromara with a five-shot lead in the overall.Owenbeg finally got going in the final game as Nathan Tumelty, Alan Telford and Collie Gibson really put Marie McNeill, Phil and Eamon Kelly to the sword.They only let their opponents score two shots as they scored steadily and heavily to run out victors by a - margin.It has to be said that Nathan was giving his team-mates an easy time with his standard of lead bowls on what are tricky mats.This win was enough to get Owenbeg the extra points and scrape an overall draw.ST MACARTANrsquoS........... MARINA........................ MARINA made the trip to Loughinisland and went home with a good eight points that keeps them the best of the rest after the top two.It was the Saints who got off to the better start with Kevin Cassidy, Ann Marie McGreevy and John Gavin winning - against Norman Gordon, but sadly this would be as good as it would get for the home side.On mat two the visiting triple of Jimmy Graham, John Cummings and Ronan Smyth were involved in a high scoring game against Francie McGreevy with both sides having multiple counts, but it was Ronan who was getting the better of them to finish winners by -.After the break it was back to a low scoring affair between Sammy Hardy, Gerry Toman and Don Corrigan, who were playing Patricia Russell, Roy McKibben and Joey Chambers, who would win the last three ends for a - win.The final game saw Raymond Gelston along with Cecilia Magill and Manzi Cullen score two threes on the first two ends but would not score again until the seventh end against Isobel Cunningham, Henry McDowell and Billy Collom, who finished strongly to win -.All in all, a good nightrsquos bowls for the visitors..prettyPhoto

title: Take back control in your life
story: SO here we are officially into . How are your New Year resolutions going How many times do you decide to lsquostop thisrsquo, lsquostart thatrsquo, and find a few weeks later that you have blown it and feel guilty and frustrated with yourself Starting all over again on the back of frustration and then pushing yourself even harder, making it increasingly dficult to stick to your resolution Breaking habits or quitting something on the surface seem like great ideas when wanting to improve your health and well-being. Irsquod love to introduce you to approaches that are foundations that last and make you feel empowered and happier in  and beyond.What I think is essential, when we want to stop a bad habit or make a change in our lives, is to make sure that we are on our own side.Self-compassion is basically being your own best friend. When we are with our best friend, we listen to them. We comfort them and speak on their behalfthey ask us to help them. To get the cogs in motion,answer yes or no to the following questions:Do you find it hard to say no Do you find it dficult to take a compliment Do you criticise yourself often Do you compare yourself to others Do you worry about what others think about you How many were answered lsquoyesrsquo Maybe after everything that we all have been through over the last couple of years,  has the possibility to be the year that you remember as the year you began to take control, to recover and heal.  could be the year when you started loving yourself more.There are three elements that I would like to introduce today that are to be consideredyou want to feel empowered and active in real self-care.AwarenessAwareness begins with the practice of noticing. It helps us be in the present moment and be calm as we take in the sights, sounds and touch mdash even taste mdash around us.Mindfulness and meditation have been trendy in recent years, but from my one-to-one counselling work, quite a few people have said that ldquoit didnrsquot work for them, or ldquoI didnrsquot really see the benefits.Once we talked about that more, we came to the realisation that they were practicing mindfulness to not feel, to escape feeling uncomfortable or to push away dficult or negative thoughts. As a practice, things changed for the better once my clients were made aware that mindfulness was to observe their feelings and observe their thoughts with an open mind as attention was gently brought back to the breath.Taking little pockets of time in our day to consciously pause, taking a few breaths in and out and observe, can immediately let our bodies and minds be calm and focused.The small daily things are the most important things to ensure real change. You can try this little exercise and be aware how your body and mind feels:S  ndash Step back.T ndash Take three deep breaths in and three slow breaths out.O  ndash Observe the thoughts and feelings in that very moment.P ndash Proceed.Awareness also involves being able to see patterns that arise in our thoughts and feelings, as well as the behavioural outcome. Kind of like detective work, we are then able to reframe our thinking, as well as breaking the familiar cycle of judgement and frustration. Just a wee word about practicing awareness mdash it is not about self control. Awareness helps us to begin to understand ourselves and develop self compassion and practice patience .Essentially, self awareness is about empowering ourselves and providing regulation of our body and mind. Self-regulation in turn, seeks to identy and reduce the causes of problems in mood, thought and behaviour.Self-control seeks to inhibit or manage such problems only when they arise. Self-control looks at old methods of punishment and reward to manage behaviour ndash maybe like the way we begin every New Year resolution mdash or every Monday, etc.AcceptanceEspecially when a New Year starts ndash therersquos this pressure to go to extreme measures, with this notion of being accepted more, to be seen and or valued more. But pretty much into the month of January we notice how it can rob us of truly living.We are not human DOINGS ndash we are human BEINGS. I have worked over the last  years as a counsellor and have heard people talk about trying to control their lives, but feeling like it was evading them more and more.Clients found themselves going harder, pushing harder, feeling exhausted, feeling helpless ndash then pulling up their socks and trying again. Although it may go against the grain of whatrsquos familiar, itrsquos healing to ease ourselves from a place of trying mdash to be perfect, as good as others, etc mdash to self-acceptance.Accepting lessens the pressure and helps us go with the flow.Self-acceptance is a journey. If anyone  needs to put pressure on us, itrsquos them who needs to deal with their own expectations mdash not us. Acceptance challenges deeply held beliefs that we are not lsquoworthyrsquo enough or lsquogoodrsquo enough to be whole. Like awareness, acceptance develops self compassion ndash a connected relationship with ourselves.In Dialectical Behavioural Therapy, there is a theory called Radical Acceptance developed by Martina Linehan, who quotes: ldquoRejecting reality turns pain into suffering.It is really tough to accept things how they are, from childhood trauma to unexpected traffic jams. It is really such a relief and sense of clarity when we realise and accept things that we are not in control of.It is absolutely OK to feel whatever we feel in the moment. Itrsquos not just sitting back and letting bad things happen of course. It is quite pro-active from problem solving based on how things actually are, self compassion when paying attention to how we feel in the moment. Meeting emotional pain head on, after all, it is what it is. Acceptance means no more unnecessary suffering.AssertionGabor Mate talks about assertion as a declaration to ourselves and to the world that lsquowe arersquo and that lsquowe are who we arersquo. Itrsquos not being simply able to stand up for ourselves mdash therersquos something more heartfelt than that.Assertion challenges the all too common belief that we must somehow justy our existence. There are lots of things that we can learn about and practice when it comes to assertion in itself, but maybe after reading the first two elements you are realising that our inidual minds, bodies and spirit are all so important.Making decisions about diets, relationships, careers, etc, usually get focused on a lot more during the month of January, as well as quitting things and going cold turkey on habits that have been part of our lives for years.Assertion isnrsquot just a quick course from a manual or podcast about tips and tricks. It is a really important statement of our being. It is a positive valuation of ourselves mdash independent of our history, abilities, personality or the worldrsquos perception of us.In regards to resolutions, assertion doesnrsquot involve action or reaction. Like I said before, it is our BEING, no matterwe take action or not. Assertion helps us be crystal clear about what we value and what is not OK with us as iniduals.From our values we can develop boundaries. Yes, let the rest of the world cope with that, or not. In fact, assertion may be the very opposite of action, not only in the sense of refusing to do something that we do not wish to do, but letting go of the very need to act at all.I really do hope that  gives you gts and wonderful surprises, as well as the comfort and support over dficult times. If you feel that you like to find out more about ways of real self care, developing good habits and creating change, you can contact me on  .For the month of January, I am offering free -minute assessment sessions. Also, keep an eye on my up and coming workshops, Spring , by logging on to www.empowercounsellingni..prettyPhoto

title: Top speed clocked at 101mph in Ardglass
story: THE Downpatrick Road in Ardglass has jumped to the top of the districtrsquos speeding hot spot list in new figures published this week.Statistics for a three-month period between November  and January  made public by the the districtrsquos Policing and Community Safety Partnership reveal that one driver was clocked at mph in the mph zone at the entrance to the village.The Strangford Road in Downpatrick, Newcastlersquos South Promenade, the Dublin Road in Castlewellan, Killyleaghrsquos Shrigley Road and the Dundrum Road in Clough also feature heavily in the latest figures.Previous speeding statistics included the Ballynahinch Road in Saintfield but there have been no figures for this busy road for a number of months after the electronic speed indicator sign mdash which recordshow fast drivers are travelling mdash was removed in response to local concern.The sign has since been relocated and speeding stats for this road are expected to be included in the next set of figures due to be published in March.Members of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Policing and Community Partnershipwere provided with the latest speed figures at their virtual meeting this week.A mph speed limit is in place at all of the locations which have speed indicator signs, except for the Strangford Road in Downpatrick. This device is located in a mph zone.A closer examination of the latest PCSP figures reveal that the mph speed in Ardglass was recorded on November  at am.In addition,  drivers were clocked at travelling over mph in the mph zone at the entrance to the village, with almost  percent of drivers detected travelling at between mph and mph. Thirty eight percent of drivers were detected driving at between mph and mph.The provision of the series of electronic devices was in response to community concern about speeding across the district and viewed as part of a major offensive on those who break the law and to encourage drivers to slow down.PCSP officials say the average speeds recorded in Downpatrick, Killyleagh and Newcastle have reduced with no change in Newcastle. However, concern remains about the dangerous speeds that continue to be recorded with some drivers showing a blatant disregard for the speed limits in place.The highest speed recorded at the Strangford Road in Downpatrick was mph in the mph zone at am, with  drivers detected travelling at over mph. Previous speeds recorded at the built-up area have peaked at mph.Residents in the built-up area, which includes a signicant number of houses, a nursing home and local authority depot, have continually expressed concern about the speed of drivers who use the busy road and argue that the speed sign needs to be relocated further back towards the Lecale Park entrance.The highest speed recorded at the Dublin Road in Castlewellan was mph at am, with  drivers recorded travelling in excess of mph, with % of drivers detected travelling between mph and mph.Elsewhere, one driver was detected travelling at mph in the mph zone at the Dundrum Road in Clough at am, with one driver clocked driving in excess of mph.In Killyleagh, a driver was detected travelling at mph in the mph zone on the approach to the townrsquos Integrated Primary School, with  drivers clocked at over mph. The highest number of offences was recorded at pm.The highest speed recorded at the Newcastlersquos South Promenade was mph, with two drivers recorded travelling at over mph. The highest number of speed offences were recorded around am.Across the council area, the latest figures indicate that recorded speeds have reduced by six percent. The average speed of cars travellingpast each sign was mph in Ardglass and Clough, mph in Castlewellan, mph in Downpatrick, mph in Newcastle and mph in Newcastle.The PCSP is planning to install seven more speed indicator signs with demand for the devices described as ldquohigh with particular interest from residents and councillors in the Downpatrick, Rowallane, Slieve Croob and Mournes district electoral areas.Local councillor Dermot Curran, who lives in Ardglass, has described the mph speed recorded at the Downpatrick Road in the village as ldquotruly shocking.He said while the number of drivers breaking the ious speed limits is reducing, there were a number ldquothumbing their noses at the restrictions in place and posing a serious danger to other road users and pedestrians.ldquoThe fact that drivers are not slowing down in built-up areas, regardless of the time of day, is a real worry. The consequences of a driver losing control of a car travelling at mph is truly frightening. The message that speed kills cannot be reinforced enough,he remarked.ldquoThere is clearly a hardcore of drivers who care little for their own safety, or that of other road users. It is an issue that must be addressed..prettyPhoto

title: Twilight vigil for Ashling
story: MEMBERS of Newcastle CCEacute and the wider community came together last week for a twilight vigil in memory of Ashling Murphy, the -year-old teacher from Tullamore, Co Offaly, who was murdered while out running.Musicians gathered at the Garden of Hope at the Lodge in Castlewellan on Tuesday night to pay their respects to the talented traditional musician with music and poetry.Ashling was an active member of the Ballyboy Comhaltas branch in Co Offaly.Many local branch members have spent time in Tullamore attending All Ireland Fleadhs and some have walked along the Grand Canal where Ashling was killed.Some of the Comhaltasrsquo younger musicians were friends with Ashling and played music with her. They enjoyed each otherrsquos company and are still coming to terms with the tragedy.Cllr Roisin Howell, who organised the event, told the assembled people: ldquoAll of us in the branch are shocked and saddened by the death of Ashling Murphy.ldquoThe brutal manner of her death has both angered and bewildered the entire nation. We stand here in the Garden of Hope, united this evening, keeping Ashlingrsquos family and friends in our thoughts and prayers.A poem by Belfast writer Helen McClements was read out and the musicians honoured Ashlingrsquos memory by playing some of the tunes they had played with her.People also left candles and flowers at the monument as the music played.The first verse of the poem is as follows:Before she went down to the Grand CanalI wondershe chanced to run earlyCatching the last of the waning sunBefore darkness fellSnuffing out the light..prettyPhoto

title: Two hour talk  to re engage with life of St Brigid and her link to district
story: THE distinctive St Brigidrsquos cross is something that many Catholics are very familiar with, including having fond memories of being taught how to make one at school which was proudly displayed at home.As the the feast day, February , approaches, the interest in the le and work of one of the worldrsquos most beloved saints is still high.Local people will have the chance to re-engage with the story of St Brigid, who is special to the Downpatrick area as she is reputedly buried alongside St Patrick in the grounds of Down Cathedral.Historian and tour guide Brigid Watson, of Sustainable Journeys Ireland, will be hosting a talk on the le of St Brigid with a demonstration of cross-making and a chance for participants to make personal crosses.Entitled Brigid Saint or Goddess, the two-hour talk will be held at the St Patrick Centre in Downpatrick from -pm next Tuesday, February , and again on February  and March .Brigid explains why the story of St Brigid and her namesake remains fascinating to her.ldquoSt Brigid is the female patroness of Ireland and one of the most widely revered saints in Ireland and beyond. She lived in the period -AD and was a visionary spiritual leader and inspirational woman, she explained.ldquoBrigid was recognised as a saint from around the seventh century and seven dferent lsquolivesrsquo of St Brigid were written which is indicative of the cult following she had.ldquoHer feast day is on February which is the first day of spring mdash Imbolc in the Celtic calendar. There are three other feasts in the Celtic calendar mdash May , Bealtaine August , Luacutenasa and November,  Samhain. Each of the feasts has associated with it a specic set of beliefs and customs.ldquoThere was a pre-Christian aspect to the feast on February . The main importance of the feast of St Brigid would appear to be that it was a christianisation of one of the key dates in the farming year in Ireland. In earlier centuries in Ireland and in many areas St Brigidrsquos day was observed as a holiday and some farming related activities were not permitted. In , the government of the Republic of Ireland decided to make the February  a bank holiday. This is an inspired choice of date for the new bank holiday.Brigid said the main customs associated with St Brigidrsquos Day are the making of St Brigidrsquos crosses the Briacutedeoacuteg and the Brat Briacutede. These customs were traditionally practiced on the eve of St Brigidrsquos feast day as according to Celtic timing, night came before day.The custom of making St Brigidrsquos crosses is still widespread throughout Ireland. There are regional iations across Ireland in the design and composition of the cross. The most common one is the simple four armed cross.ldquoThe explanation of the custom is that St Brigid made the cross when she was comforting a dying man who wished to convert to Christianity. She placed it in his hands, explained Brigid. ldquoPeople believe that the St Brigidrsquos cross offers protection from sickness and other forms of adversity for their homes, family and animals.ldquoToday in Co Down farming and non-farming families still want to get a St Brigidrsquos cross for this reason. In Ulster, a three-armed cross was placed in the stable or byre for the protection of animals. Throughout my le I have made St Brigid crosses for our home.ldquoAs a teacher I have taught groups of pupils how to make the cross. It is important that we pass on customs and traditions to the next generation and do not lose the wealth of culture we have in Ireland.She said that the Briacutedeoacuteg is another custom associated with St Brigidrsquos Day. It consisted, or consists, of a group of young people called briacutedeoga, lsquobiddiesrsquoor biddy-boys going from house to house carrying an effigy of St Brigid .The children received some donation at each house visited. Often a doll was made for the occasion. The body of the doll may have been made from a sheaf of straw. A ball of hay, straw or turnip was used to represent the head. It was usually constructed with a strong stick or churn-dash at its core.The use of the churn dash was thought to reflect the saintrsquos association with dairying. A purchased rag doll might be used. Whether a doll was made or purchased, it was a representation of St Brigid and was dressed in white.The original objective of the exercise was the collection of alms for the poor. The group always provided some entertainment for the homes visited with singing or music. The girls and boys in the group dressed up in disguise for the occasion. The custom lasted longest in Co Kerry and still survives today in a few areas.The third important custom which was widespread throughout Ireland is known as the brat Briacutede . A piece of cloth, larger than a hankerchief, was put on a bush outside the home on the eve of St Brigidrsquos feast day and it was not usually brought in until morning.Brigid added: ldquoThe belief was that when St Brigid was travelling around the country that night and she came across the cloth, she blessed it with the curative powers of her cloak. It was put away and used as a healing cloth throughout the year for sickness, pain and as protection against harm. With changes in society this custom has only survived in some areas including the south and west of Ireland.The historian said that Saint Brigid, who is strongly associated with nature and farming, is ldquoa saint for our times. With the environmental crisis facing us we can learn from the reverence which the early Celtic saints, including St Brigid, showed towards nature. They appreciated the fundamental importance of nature to humanity.ldquoThe challenges we face today are much greater than those in the th and th centuries but the need for social justice is the same. May the le of St Brigid be an inspiration to all to take action for a better world.When she died St Brigid was buried beside the high altar in the church in Kildare. Her remains were brought to Downpatrick for reasons of safety at the time of the Viking raids on monasteries and reburied with those of St Patrick and St Colmcille at Down Cathedral.To book a place at pound for one of talks visit https:www.saintpatrickcentre friends saint-brigids-day-experiences..prettyPhoto

title: george jones older sister continues to be his guiding light even though she is in a nursing home with dementia
story: U share acoustic rendition of Sunday Bloody Sunday on th anniversary of Bloody Sunday events in Londonderry   Jim Wells: I have to accept my DUP career has ended in humiliationNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPeopleGeorge Jones’ older sister continues to be his guiding light even though she is in a nursing home with dementiaFrom Shankill Airways to the radio airwaves, George Jones will go down in history as one of the most listened-to people in Northern Ireland.By Graeme CousinsMonday, st January , : pm  "       "  He thanks his older sister for setting him on his career path in music, and also, even while in a nursing home with dementia, having rekindled another dormant passion in her younger brother.George, who found fame on the showband scene through Clubsound and stood out as one of the top radio broadcasters for more than four decades, has more recently been exploring his gt for painting.He explained how brush strokes helped to lt his boredom in lockdown: “My sister Lally has been my mentor all my le, sadly she is now in a nursing home with dementia.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.George Jones has been in showbiz for more than  years“She’s  years older than me, she’s like a second mother to me.“When I was about  I did this correspondence course, in other words you were taught through the post. I took up art, I did it for about a year and that was the end of that.“Then about five years ago, my sister’s husband had died and we were clearing out the house. I found that she’d kept all of the sketches I’d done when I was  in an envelope. “I started looked at them, messing around with them, I bought some paints and started colouring them in.Clubsound in the s. PACEMAKER PRESS BELFAST“The nights I wasn’t working I was painting. In two years I must have done about  paintings for people.“It’s a blessing for me, it kept me sane, when you play every week and suddenly you stop, it hits you hard.“It relieved the boredom, it gave me something to focus on, when a painting turned out successful you felt you’d achieved something.“My biggest satisfaction is that I’ve painted memories for people that are now hanging in their house.George Jones started and finished his radio career with Downtown. Picture by CHARLES MCQUILLAN PACEMAKER.“It’s another sense of entertainment I suppose, another string to my bow. If my sister hadn’t kept those sketches I wouldn’t have all of this.”George recalled his sister’s influence on his musical career: “The first two records my sister brought in that started me on music when I was about nine or  were Little Richard ‘Long Tall Sally’ and Elvis ‘All Shook Up’. “In those days it wasn’t vinyl, it was  bakelite – it looked the same as vinyl butyou’d dropped it, it would have smashed. “I listened to them non-stop and then she bought me my first guitar at .”George said he formed skfle groups with boys of his age in the Bloomfield area of east Belfast. One of them was Van Morrison, whom George went on to tour with as The Monarchs.He said: “I go to lunch with Van Morrison quite a lot. The Monarchs were the first band to go to Germany. We had a hit record in  when the Beatles were still hovering around Germany.“Van has been trying to find the rights to it to repress it and put it out as a single on vinyl. I sung on it and he played saxophone – a bit of rock and roll.”George, who has been part of the successful ‘Do You Come Here Often ’ and ‘Rock ‘n Roll Years and Dance Hall Days’ shows, started learning the guitar at . He believes that might be the magic number: “I’ve interviewed so many people in my years on the radio who started the exact same way. “I’m hesitant to ask when they started to play the guitar – it’s always . So many great guitarists I interviewed, the likes of Hank B Marvin, started at .”Having found his first chords at  George is still going strong at .He said: “For me it’s been an incredible le, just when you think it’s all over, Clubsound have found a new lease of le.“We’ve found out that young people have started listening to the albums their parents have. I hesitate to use the term, but you become a cult.“Young ones come up to me and say ‘Yeoooo, Shankill Airways, my mum plays that all the time’.”George said the state modern music meant that people are yearning for songs from bygone days, especially the fties and sixties: “It was real music, there was no electronics – it was guitars, live drums, you were getting the whole live vibe.“In our day you just piled in, there was no such thing as tickets, you paid at the door and they squeezed in as many as they could.That added to the experience.”George plans to publish his memoirs as a book. In it he plans to recount his first meetings with Rory Gallagher and an incredibly green Gary Moore, of whom he told his father, ‘that wee lad will never be a guitar player’.‘It took a long time but I’m now over shock exit from Radio Ulster’George said that when he made his radio debut with Downtown his plan wasn’t to dilute his Clubsound persona too much.He said: “I used to bring what I did on stage onto the radio. I used to bring these we characters like Sadie that I did the voices for – she got more mail that I did. Radio needs to entertain,you’re on for two hours you’re not just sitting there spinning dics, you have to draw people in.”It wasn’t long before George was snapped up by Radio Ulster where he delivered ‘Just Jones’ for an amazing  years. Then one fateful day he was told he was surplus to requirements despite his popularity.George said: “People come up to me to this day, saying, ‘we miss you on the raido’ and ‘why did they do that to you’. “It was a big change in my le, it brought me down to earth more than anything. I thought those days were over – about two more times before that we were down and out and started over again, especially after the Miami thing and in South Africa my son nearly died of typhoid.“There were downs, but this was one I didn’t expect. I felt I was doing a good job.“During my six month notice period the public lted me to heights I never would believe. On the last week I was there I got nearly , emails from all over the world. I walked out of there about  feet tall. That was the bonus.”He said: “My we and family have helped me put it behind me. It took a long time because I was hurting.“I took up U with good success. It was water under the bridge and I had to put it under the bridge. I finished up in Downtown where I’d started in the s. Then I said to myself, radio is changing but it’s time for me to step aside.“When I look back now at radio in general, it’s like looking back to the wonder years of music, it saddens me – why has it changed so much  The commercial radio stations are just advertising boards with bits of music. “The word entertainment has disappeared from broadcasting. You couldn’t sit and listen to a radio show for two hours now, whereas before you’d have people would have been glad of that two hours of company.”Asked who he listens to on the ‘wireless’ George said: “Ken Bruce is still one of the old school and he makes me laugh. He still plays the oldies. Steve Wright still plays oldies. Asides from that it’s Classic FM.“It breaks my heart but I wouldn’t listen to any local radio stations.”Where to see George and Clubsound in actionClubsound’s current line-up of George Jones, David McKnight, Barry Woods, Alan McCartney and Jimmy Black will be on the road this spring including gigs at Theatre at The Mill in Newtownabbey on Saturday, March , Armagh’s Market Place Theatre on Saturday, April  and the Portico Arts and Heritage Centre in Portaferry on Monday, April . There will also be a gig at the Millennium Forum in Londonderry on Thursday, November . The same venue hosts ‘Rock ‘n Roll Years and Dance Hall Days’ on Saturday, February .——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityGraham Loveluck-Edwards has announced the release of his new book Historic Pubs of Wales where he relishes in some of the more colourful myths, legends and stories from Wales ancient past and oldest pubs. Included in the book is The Captains We, in Sully, a house originally owned by a captain. "I have always loved old pubs, and we are blessed to have so many belters here in Wales," added Mr Loveluck-Edwards. Graham Loveluck-Edwards out snapping some pubs for his book"For example, the pub which claims to have an elephant buried under its beer garden, or the pub where funeral parties take a short cut to the cemetery through the bar to keep an ancient right of access alive, or the pub that claims to have invented pancake day and so many more. "In all, Ive compiled over  incredible stories based around  amazing old pubs - is there any truth to them "Some for sure, but this book captures them and puts them in the context of history so you can be the judge."MORE NEWS:The book also contains a travel guide so readers can go on a tour around Wales and visit all the pubs in the book.You can find out more at www.talesfromhistoricpubsofwales.  The book is available to buy now"As you can imagine for such a book the research was relentless and thorough, and a lot of fun," he added."Pubs have had such a tough time in the last year with us going in and out of lockdowns and with the introduction of social distancing measures. "Sixteenth century inns are usually a warren of tiny rooms so being two metres apart has made opening and trading near impossible for many. "So, a book which celebrates all that is great about our old pubs, which tells people their history, where to find them and what to expect when you get there has been welcomed by all landlords." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAll sporting events in Wales will be held behind closed doors from Boxing Day due to the surge in coronavirus cases, the Welsh government has announced.Cardf CEO Mr Dalman insisted all new guidelines will be followed, but conceded another shut-out of fans will hit the Bluebirds hard.“It’s a major blow from all aspects, but we have to put the safety of our fans, players and everyone first,” Mr Dalman told talkSPORT.“So we will follow the guidelines as they are laid out.“These things are made for a reason and as much as we dislike them, we will certainly obey them.“It’s a blow of course for football, a blow for our club, because we always want to play in front of our fan base, and that’s a great shame.”Fans of Welsh football clubs should currently still be able to attend away matches in England, but Mr Dalman feels further restrictions may be in the offing.AskedCardf fans could travel to away matches in England, Mr Dalman replied: “Theoretically speaking that’s correct, in practical terms, let’s see what happens next.“There are a lot more developments to come, I’m sure of that.“So I would just wait to see the next announcements from the government as to the guidelines, and we go from there.”When askedthe EFL would be able to prise any money out of the Premier League to help offset lost revenue, Mr Dalman replied: “You know my views on the EFL, the answer is I wouldn’t hold my breath.”Economy minister Vaughan Gething announced the new measures for indoor and outdoor sporting events in a bid to slow the spread of the Omicron iant.Mr Gething said: “Sporting events over the Christmas period are one of the big highlights of the year. Unfortunately, the new Omicron iant is a signicant development in the pandemic and could cause a large number of infections..remove“We need to do everything we can to protect people’s health and control the spread of this awful virus.“Throughout the pandemic we have followed scientic and public health advice to keep people safe. The advice is clear – we need to act now in response to the threat of Omicron. We are giving people as much notice of these decisions as we can.“Crowds will come back as soon as possible. We want everyone to be here to enjoy their favourite sports.”Cardf’s United Rugby Championship clash with Scarlets and Wrexham’s National League fixture against Solihull – both scheduled for December  – will be the first affected by the ruling.And the Welsh Grand National at Chepstow will also have to be run behind closed doors despite advance ticket sales in excess of ,.Cardf City’s Championship clash against Coventry has already been postponed due to a coronavirus outbreak in the Bluebirds’ camp, as has the URC game between the Ospreys and the Dragons.The first EFL fixture due to be affected is Swansea’s Championship clash with Luton, which is currently scheduled for December .Cardf City said in a statement: “Cardf City Football Club acknowledges the instruction from the Welsh government for sporting events in Wales to be played behind closed doors for a limited period of time in an effort to curb the spread of the Omicron iant.“Following the postponement of our Boxing Day fixture with Coventry City on Monday, this is set to most immediately impact our FA Cup third round tie with Preston North End on January th.”Gething confirmed that a £million spectator sports fund will be available to support those clubs affected by the loss of spectator revenue.Chepstow racecourse chief executive Phil Bell anticipated the move last week, when he told BBC Wales: “We’ve seen this coming in recent days.“It would be damaging. measures put in place in an attempt to stop the spread of the Omicron iant of covid have helped "flatten the curve of infections".This, coupled with efforts to provide every fit and healthy person with an invitation to get their booster vaccine, has allowed the Welsh Government to put plans in place to loosen restrictions once again.The news is likely to come as a welcome piece of news for sports organisations and hospitality venues in Newport, Gwent, and the wider region.Since mid-December, restrictions have been placed on crowd numbers at sporting venues, which all but forced games to be played behind closed doors.As for hospitality, nightclubs have been closed in Wales since December , and while these traders missed out on a potentially lucrative payday on New Year’s Eve, they are now just weeks away from being able to reopen.Nightclubs reopening in Wales: Everything you need to knowFrom Friday, January , nightclubs in Wales will be able to reopen to the general public once again.As part of this, the rule of six, two-metre physical distancing requirements, and table service at pubs and restaurants will no longer be mandatory.Ahead of reopening, venues, along with all businesses and employers are required to undertake a covid specic risk assessment, to take reasonable measures to prevent the spread of the virus.And, as before, anyone looking to attend a nightclub will have to provide a covid pass as a condition for entry.What we know as fan restrictions at sporting venues ltedSports fans in Wales won‘t have to wait as long as the nightclubs toto their haunts, with restrictions on crowd numbers set to be lted on January ..removeNationally, this will be a major boost ahead of the Six Nations, but locally, it means that Newport County and the Dragons will be able to welcome fans back to Rodney Parade.The Dragons will be the first of the local sides to be able to allow fans back in, when Italian side Benetton arrive on January , before the posts are swapped out, and County welcome Barrow the following day.No limits will be placed on outdoor activities, but as before, covid passes will be required to attend games with a large scale crowd expected.What has been said about the changes Confirming news of the upcoming rule changes, Mr Drakeford said: "We able to do itonly because of the amazing hard work and effort of everyone  who have once again followed all of the rules and taken all of the steps to keep ourselves and our loved ones safe."The enormous efforts of all those working in the vaccination centres, in our NHS, in our public services, in shops and in businesses who have done so much to protect us fom this latest wave of that awful virus."Thank you - thank you to everyone who has done so much to help to keep us safe."It doesnt mean the pandemic is over." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey seperate times - forced the referee to the delay the game.Both were charged with charged with going onto the playing area, without lawful authority or lawful excuse.Walsh appeared before Cardf Magistrates Court on Tuesday, January , , and Curtis appeared at the same court on December , .Both pleaded guilty and Walsh was fined £ with £ costs, and Curtis was fined £ with £ costs.They received Football Banning Orders preventing them from attending any regulated football match in the United Kingdom for the next three years.As part of the Football Banning Orders, both men will have to surrender their passports to police whenever Wales are playing football games abroad.PC Christian Evans, from South Wales Police, said: "The overwhelming majority of Cardf football fans are well-behaved and passionate about their team"But whenever there is evidence of football-related disorder or violence we always pursue those responsible in order that appropriate action is taken."I hope this court result sends out a clear message that similar behaviour will not be tolerated at the Cardf City Stadium."A -year-old boy also entered the pitch that day but was dealt with by way of ersion, intervention with parents and a club ban.Cardf City operations manager, Wayne Nash provided the court with an impact statement.Mr Nash said: "We as a club have a duty to provide a safe, secure and welcoming environment for all persons attending and working events and as such the playing surface needs to be a place of sanctuary for the players where they can go about their work without fear..remove"If we cannot provide this secure environment, then their safety is compromised because at any moment we could have somebody enter the field of play or an area that they are not entitled to occupy and assault a player or member of staff."A Football Association fine of thousands of pounds is a possibility despite the excellent record of safety provision at the Cardf City Stadium."This Department for Transport figures.Other incentives to support commuters ing to the office include the introduction of flexible season tickets, and an easing of the rules for amending tickets. title: mark drakeford announces covid restrictions wales eased
